title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Mr. Stuart, thegrand-nephew of my dear friend Lady Louisa, also dined with us, togetherwith the Lyons from Gattonside, and the day passed over in hospitalityand social happiness.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We dined at Gattonside with Mr. Bainbridge, who kindly presented me withsix bottles of super-excellent Jamaica rum, and with a manuscriptcollection of poetry, said to be Swift's handwriting, which itresembles.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 21.--Here is a vile day--downright rain, which disconcerts aninroad of bairns from Gattonside, and, of course, annihilates a part ofthe stock of human happiness.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _April_ 9.--I wrote as hard to-day as need be, finished my neat eightpages, and, notwithstanding, drove out and visited at Gattonside.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Dined at Chiefswood with Captain and Mrs. Hamilton, LadyLucy Whitmore, their guest, and neighbours from Gattonside and HuntlyBurn.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: [317] The property of Gattonside had been purchased in 1824 by GeorgeBainbridge of Liverpool, a keen angler, author of _The Fly Fisher'sGuide_, 8vo, Liverpool, 1816.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: They were broken to pieces by afanatic weaver of Gattonside.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: He conferred on themextensive lands and privileges; the lands of Melrose, Eldun, andDernwie; the lands and wood of Gattonside, with the fishings of theTweed along the whole extent of those lands; with the right of pasturageand pannage in his forests of Selkirk and Traguair, and in the forestbetween the Gala and the Leeder, with wood from those forests forbuilding and burning.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: " Old Paradise did not number a neighbourhood among its pleasures ; but Gattonside has that advantage, and great will be the regret of the said neighbours, if Sir Adam and Lady Eve are turned out.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The estate of Gattonside was purchased about this time by Mr. George Bainbridge of Liverpool — and Sir Adam and Lady Fergusson, to Scott's great regret, went a year or two afterwards to another part of Scotland.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: He turned as I spoke, and looked across to the hills of Gattonside, where the trees were standing out clear and black against a skyline that was all saffron.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: Leaving Melrose, we crossed the Tweed's fairstream above the sunny little village of Gattonside,and presently began to ascend the pastoral vale ofGala Water, on whose opposite bank we saw theuniformly neat and busy town of Galashiels, thevicinity of which is decorated by the woods andgrounds of Mr. Scott of Gala, the superior of theburgh.
